3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
15.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 avril 2018
File under: surprisingly great first person open world platforming/exploration game.

There's been some sort of disaster brought about by the arrival of three planets. Almost everyone's been wiped out, but this isn't the type of apocalypse that makes everything look brown. In fact, once you appear out of nowhere, one of the first places you get to is downright paradisiacal.

The land you'll get to wander around in is divided into large, intricately designed areas, all beautifully rendered and most of them boasting a great eye for verticality. Your next goal is always marked, but you're free (and encouraged!) to go off-track chasing the thousands of collectibles littered everywhere. You could just chase the objective marker, but then you'd miss out a ton of places and most of the fun the game has to offer.
So, about those goals - let's get this out of the way quickly: this is not a game you'll want to play for the story. It's... well, underwhelming. The setting is interesting at first, but unfortunately this is a very talky game; any sense of mystery is quickly trampled by several characters all talking about it in pretty inane ways. I'm pretty sure I would have liked the game better if it was completely silent, with only the odd bit of context here and there. Oh well, it's not offensively bad or anything, just poorly written and full of cliches.
Mostly you'll be running around beautifully rendered, complex levels, looking for ways to get to a place that's caught your eye for some reason. You start out with a pretty fun to control parkour move set (jumping, sliding, mantling and wallrunning), and as you advance the story you get some additional powers to let you get to previously unreachable places. Most of these powers are activated by aiming at something and "firing", and that's the part where I feel the otherwise excellent controls falter. Sometimes they just don't work even though I can't tell what I did wrong. Luckily you get a limited slow motion mode to help with this.
There's also a way to change the levels themselves. It's a fun mechanic, but except for a few instances the changes don't feel as big as they probably should.
So most of the time you're getting around and solving simple traversal puzzles. The other main element of the game is dealing with a small variety of threats. There's no actual combat in the game, and all the enemies are mechanical or different type of golems - you deal with them by basically avoiding attacks or detection, and plucking out vulnerable points, which is pretty cool if a bit clunky. Wonder why most first-person parkour-centric games are so non-violent?

There are rough edges aplenty, but they're easy to overlook given just how good everything looks and how well it plays. Hell, there's a bunch of stuff I haven't even touched upon. It's a massively ambitious game made by a tiny bunch of talented folks that nails a lot of what it was going for, and it's always great to see that happen.
 
Dread Guacamole
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
12.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 juillet 2018
Downward is what happens when you cross Mirror's Edge with Portal. A pretty fun indie parkour game, containing puzzles and interesting new game mechanics.

Pros:
- Active dev team. It is almost the 1-year anniversary of the game, but they are still making improvements. Their presence in the Steam Discussions section is noticeable. I got my reply in half a day.
- The art style is original and varied. Every location looks significantly different.
- The "Mark" system aka portable checkpoints. Take the frustration out of jumping puzzles. Careful though, the charges are limited.
- 3 planet system lets you choose which planet affects a region. This changes visuals as well as unlocks new paths by altering the physics. Alpha raises water levels, letting you swim to new locations. Beta turns up the heat, raising lava levels along with new platforms and adds damage over time unless protected by a lamp buff. Gamma adds floating ruins, creating new paths in the air.
- Enemy types and "combat" system are completely unique to this game.
- 3 endings that let you see the story from a different perspective.
- You don't get bullied on 100% completion. Alternative endings unlock maybe 2/3 through your collections.
- The price is pretty low for ~10 hours worth of fun.

♥♥♥♥:
- Combat currently involves only 3 enemy types. There are no attacks so you just dodge until the enemy becomes vulnerable and then you pull out an artifact from them that makes them fall apart. Combat could use a little more depth to require special tactics other than just dodging to buy time.
- Some mechanics and skills could use a better description
- Few bugs, however nothing game breaking and let's face it, which game doesn't have them. The dev team is active and will address them.

Overall, I'd say a decent 9/10. I had fun and the game was relaxing.
 
Smartik1

15.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 octobre 2017
A good indie game using the UE4 engine. It looks really good maxed out and the game is different than other fps style games. It's a mixture of parkour in a myst like world. While some people stated the gameplay was a few hours I found myself exploring all the secrets as there are a lot of them and this can also determine a different ending if you explored a lot like I did. The other cool aspect of the game is that while you think you have explored everything in an area changing the planets will have diverse effects on the environment of the area unlocking new opportunities to access other things you couldn't reach or even see until the world was changed. There are a total of 4 different states so changing every map to access all the secrets can take a lot of exploration. Total gameplay for me was almost 16 hours and I really enjoyed it a lot. Highly recommended!!

I'm really impressed by the game so far given what it costs. I've run into some minor glitches so far, but the primary parkour gameplay is pretty solid. The game looks great and the platforming design is quite well done. The only glaring issue with the game is the voice acting. The main character is terrible and the supporting characters are only a little better. Maybe they will be able to replace some in the final version.

Évaluation publiée le 24 juin 2021
Downward es un juego de parkour y plataformas un poco del estilo de Mirror's Edge. Aunque las ideas buenas, se nota que está realizado ♥♥♥ un equipo muy pequeño de gente, lo cual hace que no llegue a brillar como podría haberlo hecho. Uno de los ejemplos donde mejor se nota esto es en la historia, que aunque tiene un comienzo misterioso y enigmático, al final en realidad tiene un desarrollo bastante pobre que no cuenta demasiado. Las mecánicas de plataformeo están bien y los mapas abiertos tienen muchas zonas que explorar y secretos que encontrar, pero al final hay pocas mecánicas lo cual lo hace algo repetitivo, aunque no es un juego largo. En la misma línea, los enemigos tienen una variedad demasiado escasa, ♥♥♥ torretas, exploradores y golems, y ya está, y el árbol de progreso y habilidades, así como los avances en la base, se sienten poco útiles y de escaso impacto real.

Gráficamente el juego cumple, aunque sin grandes aspavientos. El sonido tiene un nivel decente, quizás el mejor aspecto técnico del juego. Y yo no me he encontrado ♥♥♥ grandes bugs, pero si ♥♥♥ numerosos glitches gráficos y problemas ocasionales en las animaciones.

Por todo ello, Downward no es mal juego, pero tampoco es un juego memorable en ningún sentido. Un 6.

20.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 janvier 2019
The best way I can describe this game is: a hidden gem.
I have no idea when or why I got this game, and i decided to install it one day on a whim and HOLY CRAP I was impressed. By the graphics, the tight controls, the scenery, the gameplay. It was satisfying to say the least. You play as a jumping man who can also dash very far and climb things. I encourage you to use the dashing ability in combination with wall running to keep your speed and go way faster than you should, the game almost has a surf like feel to it. The challenges are difficult to master but not impossible.

There is a LOT of freerunning/parkour in this game, the combat comes second, but is still sufficient. This game is above all else beautiful and entertaining. There is something to be said about a beautiful game you want to just dive into.
9/10 visuals, 8/10 gameplay, 5/10 story, for an indie game? This is unheard of. If you're into freerunning or first person platformers, this is bar none. There are some things I don't like about the game, it's not perfect, but they are easy to overlook and aren't glaring. I can't reccomend it enough, give it a shot especially if it's on sale.

Bear Habitat
336 produits enregistrés

9 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 mai 2017
Avis donné pendant l'accès anticipé

A more than decent free-running free-world game
I've got to say that i enjoy this game. At 3 hours ingame there's still plot to unravel and things to discover.
(granted; i've spent a lot of time in the online meditation mode.)
Some key aspects of the game i'd note for anyone interested in buying the game would be

Narrative and plot
  • The narrative provides some pointers, but can at times seem vauge or random. This however, may be a result of the change between discussion and monologue.
  • The plot doesn't make much sense at first, but as you progress, some points become clearer.
  • The protagonists drive is unclear, and very little is told about the man you play. This makes the plot and progress slightly weird; because of the constant question of where you are, who you are, why you are doing this and how did you get to where you are. Although this might become clear in the run of the game, the unravelling of it is slow.

Game mechanics
  • The use of free running and chaining of jumps makes the movement slightly easier seeing as you don't have to time every jump on your own. The only problem with this is the fact that chaining actions won't work everywhere, and can at times seem random.
  • The fact that you don't directly fight enemies, but rather draw their attacks to exhaust them, makes the fighting fun at times. It can also cause the player to end up in a prolonged game of tag caused by the fact that you can draw attacks and just run away away from danger (this however will not be as easy when you're faced with multiple enemies)
  • The use of planets to change the environment seems very interesting even in the early periods of the game, making the world change to open new paths.
  • A problem in the mechanics and playstyle of the game, would notably be the fact that you cannot see the character you play (because of the first person pov); causing some quirky moments where your feet touch the ground unexpectedly, or causing you to hit corners, either making you bounce in weird directions, or removing all your momentum.
  • The abilities introduced to the player in the game are all interesting, but they too have some quirks, most notably is the fact that the dash has a slight incline to the left, and the fact that it is supposed to be timed with other actions, but the duration of the dash causes the player to loose momentum if they can't get off the ground quickly enough.
  • My biggest problem mechanic-wise, would be momentum, there is momentum in the game and it's used in sliding and wall running, but the moment your feet touch fast ground you loose nearly all momentum, this times with the quirky reaction of the dash at times can make keeping a high speed hard, and at times virtually impossible.

Level design and visual aesthetics
  • The entire world is pleasing to see, the integration of free running obstacles in ruins and rough environment is done nicely, giving slight clues as to what you can scale, run on or climb on in the environment. The use of red paint to mark climbable walls, and blue to mark obstacles meant for wall-running; are two of these clues.
  • The use of unpassable obstacles makes it easier to see which directions you aren't going. This however does not mean that finding the right way is easy all the time.
  • Notably the design of some online challenges have their flaws, at times actually restricting the speed at which one can complete a level, caused by the restrictive area of some of the anomalies, the size of the walls and platforms being a pain in the buttocks because of the restricted control of momentum in-air, combined with the fact that the fastest and quickest path often includes a lot of in air movement, because of the loss of momentum when hitting the ground.

All in all the game can be very challenging (mostly in online challenges so far for me), but dying is hard if one uses the abilities provided. The quirks of the mechanics only makes mastering them even more challenging and for a stubborn person like me, more fun. Although i wouldn't say that this game is the best parkour game i've played (when compared to games like mirrors edge), i would easily give this game a 4/5 on a rating, it has kept me captivated, interested, challenged and amused. Yet i'd like to add that as with most games, this one might garner completely different reactions from different players; as the old norwegian saying goes "The taste is like the bum" (Interpretations can vary, but personally i like the conclusion "yours, and not anyone elses business" although the conclusion "split/divided" migth fit the diversity of opinion more).
 
0rothorn
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
40.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 décembre 2018
"Unravel the deep mystery that lies behind the disappearance of humanity" is a bit of false advertising because you don't unravel squat. You don't get any answers, or even any real information about what happened. But you know what? Play this game anyway.

The controls are tight, the gameplay is fun, and the visual style is gorgeous. Sentient fire turtle? No backstory. Why's that woman have a bird head? No reason. What are those weird planets, where'd they come from, are you the last human on earth? No answers, period. Yes, it can be irritating when there's so many things that make you ACHE to get any hint of the story behind them, but the aura of mystery is so intoxicating you can almost forgive it for having zero payoff.

Honestly, what I want most is for the devs to write a novel explaining half the stuff in this game and after playing it you'll want that too.
 
Causality

7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 novembre 2017
The main feeling the game left me with was frustration, not enjoyment.

This is a puzzle movement game with enough parkour elements that it feels like it should be a parkour game. But it doesn't let you go fast often enough, which is what makes parkour games fun. Not enough direction, not enough open paths.

If the movement were consistently slower, this would fix that problem. Instead, the game gives you areas too dark to navigate quickly. It arbitrarily slows you down at times (like it decides you should be slowly shuffling in some areas when you think you should be able to sprint, and you end up falling to your death).

Beyond that, Downward is supposed to be a puzzle game. I got fed up with a "puzzle" of hunting for a hidden object in a small area that was horribly inconveniient to navigate. I'm pretty sure I went through the whole area multiple times. I suspect I found the artifact it wanted me to find, but the game didn't register it. Conidering this was only about twenty minutes in, that's kind of egregious.
 
Neia
269 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
14.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 janvier 2019
Now this was fun. Recently bought "Dead Core", which is similar, but enjoyed this much more. This game is a First Person Parkour game, in a fantasy setting. The story follows our unnamed protagonist as he navigates some kind of ancient ruins after a civilization that annihilated itself in some kind of war. The world is controlled by 3 planets that when activated (!) cause changes in the world (opening and closing routes in the map).

The game is gorgeous, runs very smoothely and have very little problems overall. The ending I got was very disappointing (and ambiguous), but I gather there are more and I might just play it some more to try to get some additional collectibles.

Worth it for anyone who liked Mirror's Edge, or Dying Light but didn't like the hand to hand combat (or firearms, or zombies :) ).
 
SciBoy

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
8.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 juillet 2017
Just did a play through of the game. Took about 5 hours running around grabbing everything, Recommending yes if you get it on sale.

Pros:
Nice looking
Interesting levels
Kept my attention long enough to finish it.

♥♥♥♥
None of the puzzles are challenging.

The wall running can be very frustrating. Sometimes your doing great others it hates the wall your running on and wont grab it. Same with the jumping back and forth between walls. You do 4 jumps and the 5th just wont grab. Tends to get a bit frustrating having to do the same sequence several times to get through the area.

The "Combat" is mindnumbingly easy. Run at bosses slightly pointed to the side, boost past it. turn wait to see what pattern it is doing, rinse repeat, doesnt matter how many you are up against, Can easily kill all of them that way. Same with drones, or just run to them then run around in time to click gem on their backside. Got really repetitive and boring.

End boss was a bit of a joke, especially if you use your recall.

I know I am making it sound worse than it is. It kept my attention long enough to finish it so not a bad deal if you grab it on a steam sale.

Exploit spoiler below ....














There is a really bad exploit. All the orbs you are trying to collect will respawn if you quit and restart your save, So before jump down to "start your adventure" you can collect all the orbs, hit a bell, ext to menu, continue and all the orbs are back up. Since one of the abilities allows you to get double and eventually triple the amount for everything you collect, if you spend 30 min doing this, you can max everything before you even start playing the "real " part of the game
 
SenaSmrt
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
24.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 septembre 2020
This is more fun than it has any right to be.
It is impossible to play with a controller. You will get bugged at one point or another. Jump direction is affected by directional input mid flight so if you have to switch directions often you will fall off fifty times and then avoid that place for the rest of the game once passed. Wall runs are inconsistent depending on how close to the wall the game thinks you are. The combat is easy once you realise what on earth is even happening. The story has mistaken not telling the player anything for depth and a footnote for an ending. Exactly 2/3 of the game is optional content and the remaining 1/3 is not particularly long. It's not exactly a parkour game because you will spend half of the time carefully evaluating whether you can make the jump or not cause you've been hurt before.
Bought this game on launch because thePruld, and ragequit on the boss because it is unforgiving and ripped me into pieces. Came back three years later and changed my philosophy.
Once you accept the jank, become the jank and internalise the jank, it's an incredibly fun platformer with magic and an excuse for a plot that is meant to be a weekend killer. It's a valiant effort by a bunch of indie devs of making something new and arcady with their sole mistake of advertising it as anything more than that. The planet mechanic, different powers and somewhat variable paths are fun, the game is pretty and it's a shame the company did nothing more interesting.
 
Kai
651 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
9.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 janvier 2021
Nice eye-candy, but that's pretty much it.

The games' tutorial system is poor; it doesn't introduce you to the game mechanics in an orderly fashion, and the 'tutorial' menu just has a list that you can click on, regardless if you've unlocked that thing or not.

The writing is poor; this definitely wasn't their focus. Simple, stupid things, like when you talk to the skull, and he talks about the teleportation mechanic; "...that which you quaintly call 'the mark'." Only, you've not said more than ten words to the skull, and you certainly haven't told him about that. Or when the caged lady is released and disappears, and there's no clue as to what to do, only surprise! You have a quest marker with no explanation. Or the fact that the 'artifacts' are never used by the player, but assumes that they are really powerful and dangerous. In movies/games/animation, the rule is Show, Don't Tell; no effort is made to show anything.

Basically, this is just a parkour game, that throws some pittance of dialogue at you. If you don't mind that, then it's not half bad.

Also, wtf is up with the skull decor? The only other person wandering about for supposedly hundreds of years is the Merchant. And who keeps refilling the torches?

Évaluation publiée le 6 juin 2020
Muy buen juego de plataformas 3D, lo compre porque me recordo a ''A Story about my uncle'' y a ''Portal'' pero es algo mas que eso, logra una identidad propia.

-Los graficos son buenos, el juego va fluido y en ningun momento sufri bajones de FPS.
-La historia es simple, lo suficiente como para querer llegar al final y descubrir un poco mas sobre este mundo.
-La banda sonora es buena.

En conclusion, cumple lo que promete y mas. No es una obra maestra pero es divertido y bastante recomendable.

885 produits enregistrés

8 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
15.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 septembre 2017
Downward is a relaxed and casual experience, where you can fully enjoy yourself with the scenery and let your inner parkour get out, as you explore and jump around all over the place. Exploration is really rewarding and more often than not, there are multiple paths and ways to get around, sometimes you won't even be sure of the way to your objective.
The graphics are quite nice and enjoyable while you are getting your parkour skills top notch
It might not be as games like Mirror's Edge, and it may still need some polishing... but Downward is a gem on its own and it has many points on it's own, and at a very fair price.

If you are looking for combat or something like that, this isn't it. There is no combat whatsoever here, even if there are enemies, it's not like you actually fight them attacking them. The game focuses on the parkour and exploration, and so far it has been an amazing experience.

There might be a minor thing or two that still needs sorting out, but nothing annoying or that could ruin this great experience so far. So if you are looking for a good exploration game, nice views and parkour... check this out, you won't regret it.
 
Eisvogel

Al mismo tiempo, le falta algo más de poder narrativo, pero ello no impide instantes dinámicos dentro de una historia que abarca más de 10 horas de juego.

0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
5.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 septembre 2018
На безрыбье и рак рыба

Паркурно-прыгательно-бегательная бродилка с собиранием всяких ништяков и лазанием по скалам в нарко мире. Бежим по маркеру, через полосу препятствий за артефактами и отбиваемся от злых камней. Есть прокачка, правда игру и без неё возможно пройти. Управление вменяемое и интуитивное, привыкания не требует. Есть какой-то сюжет. Иногда нужно подумать, как действовать дальше, но ничего сложного за всю игру не встретится. Так-же в игре есть бестолковая кастомизация жилища, да жилище тут тоже есть, подобие его. Графен приятный. Музыка не выразительная, но под стать происходящему. Харизматичный глав герой. Есть альтернативные концовки.
Фишка игры - менять, как я понял, атмосферу планеты, при этом на уже знакомой локации повятся левитирующие камни по которым можно пройти дальше или повысится уровень воды. Утонуть нельзя, но можно разбиться с высоты об мелководие.
О минусах:
Поведение врагов невменяемое, хотя, возможно у живых камней и не должно быть айсикью за 200. Есть баги, а как же, щас бы на движке четвёртого анреала игры без багов делать. Улететь за текстуру это запросто, но к чести разработчика скажу, что все тригеры цепляния за уступы и отталкивания от стен работают отлично. Скучноватый мир и малая продолжительность игры, хотя возможность лишний раз побегать, поискать токены и плюхи ради прокачки и альтернативных концовок - имеется, что увеличит продолжительность игры ещё часа на два-три. Требовательность к железу. Альтернативные концовки имеют минимальные отличия друг от друга.
Добавлю ещё пару минусов лично от себя:
Русский отсутствует, но мне его никто и не обещал при покупке.
Мутный бекграунд. Так уж получилось, что в играх я люблю рассматривать задний фон, ещё со времён второй кваки. Пусть в 2д, пусть на скайбокс натянутый, но если он есть - уже хорошо. В этой игре блюр замыливает весь фон, особо не полюбуешься.

Наверное не стоит покупать за полную цену, чтобы пройти игру за 6 часов(+3 если на фул прохождение). Лучше уж дождаться распродажи и взять со скидкой. Я вот так и поступил.
 
S.R.-.71

Recommandé
18.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 avril 2019
Honestly this is probably one of my favourite games. I wish it was longer (story wise) and the world was bigger. I hope the creators make a second one with a bigger map. The re-playability of this is good with all the challenges in the challenge world, but eventually even that ends. The story is enough to keep you interested but you play for the game mechanics and the looks and the parkour system that is truly unique. It's better (and longer) than "A Story About My Uncle" in terms of the extent of abilities and the (though limited) open world.
It really is a great game and after finishing the story and a lot of the challenges I found myself looking for another game like it, but there really isn't much like it. It's simple and stunning; simply stunning.
 
The Superior T-Swizzle

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 janvier 2019
Sublimes ambiances.

Pour différentes raisons, (budgétaires comme esthététiques), l'univers du jeu peut sembler vide; mais c'est ce qui semble convenir à la direction artistique de ce-dit univers. En effet, on se sentira seul au sein de ce jeu, ce qui sera en adéquation avec le scénario, qui restera sobre mais efficace.

(ne pas se fier à mon temps de jeu, qui ne prend pas en compte le temps de jeu Offline)
J'ai pris plaisir à me perdre durant des heures entières, à l'image de celles que l'on pouvait passer plus jeune dans un Zelda, sans internet ni solution pour trouver la certaine porte ou le petit dialogue avec lequel il fallait intéragir pour faire enfin avancer l'aventure.
Des heures simples, passées à dénicher un petit item, à triturer le moteur physique du jeu, à "Parkourir" les plate-formes lévitantes, et capturer quelques photos souvenirs de décors somptueux.


En utilisant des mécanismes sommaires du jeu de parkour et d'exploration, son scénario à la mélodie simple, soutenue sur fond d'une harmonie de décors déjà-vus, résonne comme un morceau de musique minimaliste à la Glass ou Einaudi : Facile à écouter, mais émouvante.
 
Dr. O' Zophile

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé

Évaluation publiée le 10 février 2019
Fun game with some pretty good platforming, I enjoyed the art style. Pretty impressive for such a small dev team. Ending was a little weak but still worth playing through. It did suffer the all too famous "you can remap your controls to anything but on screen prompts wont show correct mappings". Annoying but still fun.

Get it on the cheap and try it out
 
ShXIII

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
6.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 janvier 2019
Impressions:
J'ai acheté ce jeu de par l'ambiance surréaliste et une impression de gameplay à la Mirrors Edge.
Après l'avoir finit, mes impressions:

=> Les plus:
- Très joli esthétiquement. Côtés surréalistes et fanstastiques omniprésents (se contente de concepts simples dans le domaine tels des iles flotantes et des couleurs surnaturelles, mais l'impression globale est réussie.)
- Pépins de gameplay majeurs (grapins et bords) et crashs semblent résolus. (reste juste quelques rares et petites optimisations à faire. Je n'ai eu aucun crash ou bug notable.)
-Des modes de parcours en bonus tout à fait jolis et sympas pour ceux qui veulent maitriser le gameplay simple (trop?) mais efficace.
- Doublages réussis
- Musiques d'ambiances simples, mais font bien leur office.
- Gameplay fluide...

=> les moins:
-... mais pas grand chose à faire avec ormis le parcours car le monde est plutôt vide (en thermes de gameplay, pas d'esthétique):
Un arbre des talents dépendant d'une monnaie à collecter, des zones à débloquer via des cubes à collecter, des "pseudo-combats"... ... et c'est tout
- "combats" sans aucun intérêt: le bestiaire se résume à 2 créatures + le boss du jeu. C'est tout. vraiment.
-L'IA: que fait-on pendant ces combats?
~Golems: on esquive une ou deux fois, ou les laisse marteler le sol bêtement pendant qu'on est à 2km puis on ôte leurs noyeaux quand ils sont fatigués de taper pour rien.
~Machines kamikazes: On les laisse s'approcher pour lancer leur auto-destruction à retardement, et on s'éloigne vite-fait.

-dernier point, mais non le moindre: le... "scénario".
C'en est à un état embryonnaire ; comme si vous lisiez la préface d'un bouquin, puis que... c'était tout.

[DEMI-SPOIL: histoire non racontée mais trame "scénaristique" oui]
Voici les caractéristiques de cet univers:
- scénar vide: on rassemble trois objets, on fait deux idioties évidentes, on voie si on peut les rattrapper et c'est finit.
- univers vide: juste la mention que des esprits brillants ont créé des technologies de fou, que les peuples d'alors se sont éteints par peur des autres et avidité, puis... ben c'est tout. On apprend rien de plus de cet univers.
- Personnage principal bien plus bête que ses pieds (qui eux savent que faire) et incapable de voir venir une arnaque
grosse comme une montagne malgré de multiples avertissements.


EN RESUME:
Si vous souhaitez voir de beaux paysages surréalistes et vous ballader dedans, vous pourrez aimer ce jeu.
Si vous aimez les jeux de plates-formes au gameplay simple, vous pourrez aimer ce jeu.
Si vous aimez un gameplay riche, des combats dynamiques, des énigmes ou une histoire intéressante ou captivante, passez votre chemin.

J'ai pour ma part beaucoup aimé les décors et des bases de gameplay solides, mais finit déçu par tout le reste.
Je n'y jouerais que quand je voudrait me ballader dans de beaux levels.
 
Onyx

420 produits enregistrés

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
14.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 décembre 2018
This game does have problems; the animations aren't very fluid, its not very intuitive, the wall running can be frustrating to pull off, the story is just little pieces here and there, there's a little tutorial menu you can read but most of the things you read about you can't use yet, combat is clunky, but despite all of that this game really grew on me and became a flawed gem. It reminds me of Prince of Persia (2008) and Mirror's Edge. The gameworld is presented very well and for the most part it runs pretty well. The platforming and parkour (when you pull it off) can be a lot of fun. With an ability you get called 'the mark' you can place a marker that you can always teleport back to, so in effect its a safety net. Use the mark on a safe spot and you're free to try to make those seemingly impossible jumps and if you miss just quickly teleport back before you die. You do lose sky pieces when you die, but don't be discouraged, the sky pieces respawn and you can unlock skills that slowly reduce the penalty until negating it entirely as well as skills that double and triple the amount that you earn.

The planetary influence mechanic is pretty interesting as well and adds a decent twist to the gameplay. There's a challenge mode called 'meditation' that's a big playground to practice the parkour and earn extra skypieces if you need them. If you like platforming and wall running then you will probably like this game, it just a requires a little patience and willingness to look past its flaws.
 
Aquarius
354 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
9.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 aout 2018
I've been craving a game like Mirror's Edge for a while now, and this is finally it. It hits the nail on the head. Instead of a city, we're exploring ancient ruins and a cliff on the shore. There's some strange planetary magic that changes the world and opens up new paths. But it still has all the visceral feeling of running and jumping in first person that I loved about Mirror's Edge and haven't seen until now.

What makes this game unique is that is has some items you need to collect to open up new mobility options. Some of these artifacts give you abilities, and some of them let you unlock Planets which are a sort of mode you can set a level to. Each planet has its own rules and makes the world change in different ways, so there are essentially 4 different versions of each of the levels in the game.

This made me want to rush through the game to unlock everything and then spend more time exploring when i had all my options available. I think if I was a more impatient person, or someone less in love with this type of game, I'd have spent the 4-5 hours getting to the end and I'd be done with this game. But I DO love this kind of game, and this game offers so much without demanding it.

I just beat the final boss and my first thought was, "Wait a second... I missed so much. How could this possibly be the end??". But that's not the end. There are two characters who hint at giving you a longer story, and you'll get it if you explore the world and collect enough items. You can finish this game 3 different ways (I believe!) depending on who you talk to to finish the game. And to get those endings, you'll have to explore a lot and get good at parkour.

In short, here's my review: I think the controls, map design, art direction, sound, voice acting, graphics, and general juiciness were all excellent. Almost everything in this game was A+ as far as I'm concerned. What I think were a little weak were these:

1) The writing was very vague and it was hard to feel motivated to keep going based on the story. I know it's not a story based game, but I'm really only looking for the extra endings because I love the gameplay. I think the general idea of the story is great, but the writing itself is just a little weak, it's too verbose. You should say a lot more with a lot less. I found the cut scenes often dragged on when there really wasn't that much being revealed, and it was really just an issue with phrasing.

2) I'm not sure how to fix this one, but revealing so many paths you can explore later with the strange particles floating in the air made me realize this was a game where i needed to come back after I beat the game to fully explore it. I instantly knew what those things meant and started rushing through the game so I could come back later. I think making those things less obvious, even invisible, would have made me take more time with the game.

3) This game is pretty buggy! I hate to put this in a review so i will make posts about specific bugs I found, but I frequently found myself soft-locked, and once in an infinite loading screen. There was also the issue of (what i think is) streamed map loading, which, with my slow hard drive, meant I would sit at the opening of a door, looking into the void, to wait for what was through that door to load. The first time i saw that I walked through and fell into the abyss, so I learned to wait.

That is all I have to say against this game.

I don't think I have the space to fully describ all the things I loved about this game though. The animations, the movement, the map design, the sound design, all were perfectly put together to make this game immersive enough like I was scared to fall off a cliff, even though I could teleport back (if I remembered to put down a mark). Every time I saw a float tower or a rock in the sky, I would try to figure out how to get to it and usually, there is a path. This game is full of secrets and I'm not sure if it's deliberate, but I don't think I ever ran into an invisible wall while playing, just death traps when I'm obviously out of bounds. I really appreciate this kind of map design in a mobility based game, and I wish other developers would take hints.

If I could give one piece of advice to developers, it would be this: write your stories more clearly, and expand on this game instead of making a new one. I would love to see the story of this game improved on and expanded. I think this game just needs to be bigger and the story is demanding answers all over. Please make this game bigger!

tl'dr if you loved Mirror's Edge and want more, this game is for you.
 
catseatingdogs
1,760 produits enregistrés

Nemo
0
10 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
39.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 aout 2017
This is one of the more enjoyable parkour games out there, probably one of the best for Linux, near zero violence level and just simple explore and collect to power up your stats. The story line is engaging and takes a couple interesting turns that are unexpected, at least until the end after you face the final boss and ending(s) are nothing more than a short monologue.

The game has a gorgeous environment, which you can change, and some very interesting and fun concepts and mechanics that are a little outside of the normal parkour game that makes this an enjoyable gem of a game.

My only complaints are the game ramps up the difficulty in huge steps towards the end of the game, it is fairly easy to get 2/3 of the way through this game, then some mechanics are added that increases the difficulty immensely and leads to frustration since you must quickly master the skills which takes more time than the game allows for, leading to frustration. Once good example of this is the final boss, up to this point bad guys or "mini-bosses" where fairly simple and more of a slight annoyance than anything, but going from the normal monsters to the boss is like going from fighting a street thug to fighting Superwoman, and took me I don't know how many attempts to beat the first time. The second issue I had was graphical glitches, lots of them, getting stuck behind or inside walls, under ladders, and other places I could not get out of without exiting and restarting the game, which can set you back a LONG way.

Word of advice, find the objects and use the Merchant's Lair... build stuff there, doing some investigation into certain bad guys will help a lot in the final battle. (hint, hint)

I initially starting playing this game with a controller, but discovered quickly that just didn't work because you couldn't map some of the necessary functions to buttons, and could not map the joystick buttons to anything (they didn't register at all) so I highly recommend using the keyboard/mouse controls.

The game ran well on my Linux box (FX-8230e/16GB RAM/Nvidia GTX680) on highest settings and I had no quality or frame rate issues in the graphics, even with multiple other windows and workspaces running.

I have spent close to 40 hours in this game, just exploring and gathering stuff, but it can easily be completed in probably 10 hours or so (speedrunners are doing it in less than an hour). Not many games do I go back to after completing all possible endings, but I did for this one several times and I still haven't uninstalled it.
 
acejavelin

Évaluation publiée le 30 octobre 2020
This game is extremely unpolished and is VERY clearly an indie game. With that said, I still managed to enjoy myself much more than I thought I would at the beginning. The visuals are very nice most of the time and the sound is pretty decent. The voice acting is mostly bad with only 2 performances that were even remotely good. The writing is pretty terrible. The exploration is pretty good and the parkour mechanics are spotty, sometimes feeling really good and sometimes feeling really bad. Overall if you are ok with an average parkour based exploration game with really good visuals, then I can recommend this to you.

Évaluation publiée le 22 juin 2018
A bit buggy, and a bit frustrating. Items/quest markers kept not turning up for me. This resulted in one time when I went down to the bottom after climbing for 10 minutes or so to get to an artifact (the lava area), only for the quest marker to turn up back at the top, with no shortcut to get back... so I did the whole damn climb again. That was the worst instance, but the rest of the game was pretty badly marked out, resulting in a lot of stints where I realised I was going in completely the wrong direction, or discovering areas that were totally beyond the skills I'd unlocked.

And that sounds bad! But the platforming is fun enough, there an impressive amount of things to do, and its quite pretty. I keeping it more linear would have boosted the 'parkour-is-fun' aspect. So honestly, for £4 this wasn't a bad buy. There's no 'eh, maybe' rating on steam though.

Incredibly beautiful first person platformer. Its relaxing, fun, and I stress, beautiful. It is a short game of 7-11 hours (with additional hours in the form of challenges), so keep that in mind when purchasing and you won't be dissapointed.

While the game's combat loses its lustre quickly, many of the golems you come across (all but one, if I recall correctly) are optional. The game provides plenty of the blocks they drop so you don't have to worry much about the game's combat. Focus on the platforming.

Évaluation publiée le 19 décembre 2016
Avis donné pendant l'accès anticipé

Downward is an interesting case.

The game itself is relatively simple, depending on a few mechanics to help progress gameplay (artifacts). The map is vast, with collectibles and side puzzles scattered around.

Coming from a background of speedrunning in Mirror's Edge: Catalyst, I have to admit that this game features some clunky gameplay. Not all movement is intuitive, nor fluid.

However, for day1 of an early access game, this game sufficently meets my expectations.

My full gameplay of this game can be found here:
Vidéo YouTube™: Downward Speedrun | Any% 21:26.8 (Former World Record) 
Vues : 1,185
Pretty straightforward. Nothing special except suicide abuse. Category Info: This is an early access any% speedrun. In this version, 12/19/16, the game only includes gameplay up to the placing of the...

0
Non recommandé
0.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 décembre 2016
Produit remboursé

Avis donné pendant l'accès anticipé

"Ugh"

About sums up the quality of the voice acting, and my opinion on the game, to be honest.

+

* The game looks very pretty.
* The levels seem well designed

+/-

* The general mechanics and control systems are... "okay". There's nothing inherently wrong with it, but it's also not exactly the best, either.

-

* There doesn't seem to be much of a story. Nothing grips you from the moment you start playing. You're just this guy in a brand new world. That would be fine, however, if your character was either more engaging or just shut up. This brings me onto the next part.

* The character. Man, what a load of drivel. He just wouldn't shut the f*** up. "Ugh." "ooh". "OOH". And any other ways of expressing a minor grunt type comment. That was accompanied by rather unhelpful "tips" like "that's not how you do it"... well if he already knew, he could damn well tell us. He could fall off a huge pillar and you'd hear a "ugh" as if he'd tapped his leg on a shrub.

* The game does a poor job of teaching the mechanics. It's very haphazard and random. It'll introduce some mechanic like the marks, then say "oh you need an artifact to use that" then mention nothing about artifacts for ages.

* The quality from the developer(s) in regards to grammar, punctuation and spelling is atrocious. My God just run your text through a spell checker first. Multiple, easy words are misspelled, small case 'i' at the start of a sentence etc.

* There's no quality in the character development from the NPCs you meet along the way. Everything seems very generic and bland.

* The voice acting sounds like some bored teenager got coerced into doing it as a favour. You hear more enthusiastic voicing on a soap opera...


Overall - do not recommend...
 
Beep Beep I'm a Sheep

7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
8.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 septembre 2017
Tout d'abord, Downward n'est pas un jeu de parcours. C'est un jeu de platforme et d'exploration en monde ouvert. Et Il est trés bon dans ce style.

Le côté exploration est la partie qui me plait le plus. Le Jeu est beau et non linéaire, ce qui donne envie de fouiller l'environnement. De plus, il est construit comme un metroidvania. Certains endroits seront débloqués lorsque de nouveau pouvoir seront aussi débloqués. Ainsi, le gameplay évolu avec l'exploration.

Le Gameplay a de trés bonnes idées en matière de platforme mais a tout de même quelques défauts. Pour moi, le gameplay ressemble plus à du Prince of Persia: les sables du temps qu'à un Mirror's Edge. Et retrouver les sensation de PoP est trés agréable !

Les côtés positifs :
+ Les graphismes
+ le platforming avec différent pouvoir qui ouvre de nouveau chemin pour l'exploration
+ l'exploration
+ des updates fréquentes

Les cotés négatifs :
- certains élements de gameplay mal équilibrés comme le grappin
- Bug d'affichage et de chargement de map
 
Mox Antia
1
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
15.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 mai 2021
I normally don't go in for the platformer parkour type games, as they often tend to be far too picky about perfect timing and flawless jumps, but this one caught my eye on a fantastic bargain, and the art style intrigued me. On top of that, there's a demo you can try, and both the demo and the full game have native Linux builds which (at least for me) both ran flawlessly and performed exceptionally well, even on "Ultra" graphics settings (which it defaulted to right from the first run on my system). Turns out that while challenging, it's not insanely unbeatable like some similar games I've tried in the past. The controls are responsive, and the jumps are somewhat forgiving if you're not totally perfect every time. The storyline and puzzles have been entertaining enough thus far, and I'm sure that like Portal 2, I'll probably play this one straight through to the end, if for no other reason than just to find out how the story turns out. If you can catch this on a bargain, it's 100% worth buying, but truth be told, I wouldn't have felt bad paying full price for this one. Feels worth it to me.
 
Bloo Alien
0
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 aout 2017
This game is special.

It is a relaxing exploration & collection game with a unique style. It is very enjoyable, and while I decided to boot it up to check it out, I ended up playing it for hours. Think like a platformer collectathon.

What impressed me the most was the level design. I just kept exploring, and before I knew it, I would be in this crazy lava world climbing a giant talking tortoise. The game has voice acting for a few key characters, along with the protagonist. The writing and acting gets the job done.

On my way back to deliver some bones to a talking skull, I would find a path I hadn't noticed before. I guess my skull friend can wait.

You will also soon meet a wierd old guy. He lives in a sewer. The sewer is a pretty interesting area. It can act as a home base of sorts, and you can even customize it, adding your own lighting, rooms, and decorations. This part was awesome, and was reason enough for me to go out and collect more cash money to afford the upgrades. The customization had a nice setup of options, but please give me more devs!

It has parkour. However, the parkour doesn't have quite the depth of something like Mirror's Edge, but it doesn't need to.

You are in this gorgeous world filled with floating islands and rocks, with various biomes. You collect various goodies and explore. Things you can grab are marked clearly, and I see this as a pro in this case.

You can run on walls, jump, grab ledges...all the normal stuff. However, you can also drop beacons that you can freely portal back to. You can drop them before you explore a lower area to quickly get back up high, or you can use them to avoid death/retry jumps. There are also floating sprite thingies. I can only use one, and it allows you to get a big boost/double jump.

The main collectable is a boxy thing that looks like the item in the logo. It allows you to open various light walls that block your progress.

There are statues where you can upgrade various stats, and others where you can "meditate". Meditation takes you to a practice area (it's really cool) and there are also time trials you can do to get currency for level ups.

There are also enemies. They aren't the most interesting to fight, but they keep things fresh. The major enemies reward you with more boxy light wall openers, so they are definitely worth fighting. You have a dodge, but its a bit wierd (you can only go forward & back). However, if you take any damage from enemies or falls, there are plenty of save points and healing fountains littered throughout the world. Dying does lose you a bit of your held currency to give it some weight, but it doesn't feel too punishing.

I played on a controller. I usually play first person games with a kb+m, but for running type games I like a controller. There are a few precision aim things you need to do, but the controls felt great all around.

There are some wierd bugs and other issues, but they aren't a big deal.

This review is basically my experience with the game. I went to do something and just started wandering around and really enjoying myself. Try it.
 
stoolio
4,291 produits enregistrés
0
8 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
8.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 juin 2017
Avis donné pendant l'accès anticipé

UPDATED AFTER FULL RELEASE

I'm impressed, positively. This game it's a fusion beetween an rpg, mirror's edge and the talos principle, everithing with a strong platform taste. You go around free in this wasted lands, parkouring and "fighting enemies" (you can avoid most of them if you want), collecting objects and improving your character. If you go far too soon there are stronger enemies that kills you, wich is nice, being a platform-parkour game I like that combats are avoidable, and useful only if you need artifacts to explore more.

Level Design: I love that you never know if a passage brings you in a small room or in another different "world", it gives me a great sense of exploration like dark souls 1. Also the quality of the graphics enhanced the desire to explore.

Voice Acting: Nice voice acting, I was in love with the woman's voice that guides you, (spoiler) at least until I saw who she was. The old man its great.

Parkour: it is less fast-oriented than ME and more relaxing, more platform. This works ok with metroidvania level design. The difficulty of the parkour is well-balanced, never frustrating and the mark it's an ingenious add, a lot like POP but faster and more useful than the time-mechanics


In conclusion: I feel that this game it's something that the market needed, it has some small bugs but it seems that the devs are open to feedback and being their first game it's a very good start for me.
Worth the price if you like exploring, platforming or the visuals of the game, but don't expect a AAA game for this price (in both negative and posirive meaning)
 
UltraDrumLover
0

Avis donné pendant l'accès anticipé

One of the most beautiful games I have played in awhile. The parkour is easy and smooth just the way I like it. What makes this game hard is not the mechanics, but the obstacles. I am playing with a gamepad and the controls are simple R2 to jump and wall run.

The story is kinda hard to follow and I don't always know where I am suppose to go but everything is so fun to look at I mostly don't care. The main charcter has great voice acting too.

Non recommandé
1.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 juin 2018
Produit remboursé

One of the first times I had to refund a game. Maybe some issues might resolve if I had higher playtime but I highly doubt it since I watched some other gameplay parts out of curiosity.

Pros:
- Game works, no crashes and acceptable framerate for the engine used.
- Aesthetically the game looks fine, graphics are good and animations (not gameplay, just the animations) are also great although they can be a little too slow sometimes.

♥♥♥♥:
- Gameplay is boring, enemies are extremely repetitive (there are only 3) and don't seem to add anything other than to annoy you.
- Parkouring feels very clunky, sometimes it just doesn't work when trying to wall run or chain wall jump (maybe they could've make it more forgiving to ensure smoother gameplay and give us more control?).
- In the game you have these orbs you need to collect to purchase upgrades. This system itself is fine, but they are littered everywhere, to the point where they just aren't fun to collect anymore. Sometimes they can even hinder gameplay if they're put in places where you're supposed to go if you fail certain parts, meaning that (as someone who likes to go for all collectables) you need to intentionally fail to get them. Note to developer: make them worth more but less common, don't litter them everywhere and give them as a reward rather than an obstacle, leave that to collectibles that don't influence gameplay in any way.
- The voice acting is awful, this wouldn't be an issue for me (I rather have a talking protag than a completely silent one) but he just keeps on talking. Sure, it's fine for him to ask questions or give reactions, but don't let him say something for everything he does, drink from a fountain (basically a resupply point for health and other things) or when collecting any sort of collectables.
- It was a poor idea to make this game open world, this leads to frustrating moments where you simply don't know where to go or aren't sure if you're going to the right path. sure, the blue doors (basically a stopping point to ensure you have enough "fragments") helps but it doesn't solve the entire problem.
- Although I didn't fully finish the game, I know from others that the boss is pretty bad/hard, but I can't comment on this myself.

Some nitpicks:
- certain particles (often used as jump pads) are pretty unnoticeable, they seem to blend in with the sky making them very hard to see at times.
- I think hints don't update with changes to the button mapping (not 100% sure about this though).
- The way to kill the first enemy should've been clearer. I first thought you had to ignore him and use parkour to get out of the "arena", I looked online for the answer only to stumble upon someone that seemed to have the same problem as me. You ended up needing to dodge his attacks A COUPLE OF TIMES before you can actually kill him (killing him as in left clicking his back once). This is something you simply cannot figure out with no help.

In conclusion, this game could have been better if it knew its problems earlier on. The basic mechanics needed a lot more work, especially for a parkouring game.
The price is a bit too high, 6 euro (on sale) was just a bit too much for what it’s worth. I think around 4 euro would honestly work better.
If I had to be 100% critical, I would give it a 3/10, but considering the small dev team and ignoring the price, I give it a solid 6/10. Maybe I will pick this game back up in the future, but not anytime soon.
 
Tomaarten
593 produits enregistrés
1
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

0
Non recommandé
1.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 mai 2022
Для игры, в которой паркур - это главная механика, в ней нет отточенности. Дёрганная камера - движения то слишком резкие, то слишком плавные; трудно рассчитать возможности персонажа - дальность прыжка, скорость уворота, сила отпрыжки, дальность бега по стене; противники скорей ощущаются растягиванием игры, нежели препятствием, к тому же они не требуют знания главной механики; некоторые паркурные головоломки слишком замудрёные, из-за чего теряется скорость и чувство "потока"; и главное - нету чувства скорости и высоты.
Большинство "грехов" можно было бы простить, скажем, из-за мира и атмосферы, но и их в этой игре тоже нет. С самого начала нас кидают хрен пойми куда, хрен пойми кому - ни загадки мира, ни интереса.
Графика в игре действительно красивая - разработчики смогли заставить Unreal Engine 4 показать свою красоту. Разве что, слишком яркая и, со временем, начинает рябить.

Честно, не знаю что я ожидал от инди игры - то ли "духовного наследника" Mirror's Edge, то ли "заменителя" Mirror's Edge. Но если и вы искали что-то похожее - то эта игра ею не является. Не рекомендую.
 
Osomecat

Recommandé
10.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 aout 2018
Simplistic Bliss

Definitely couldn't pass this up while it was on sale. The only other game of this style that I've played is Mirror's Edge. While the parkour mechanics of this game aren't as mature or numerous, it is definitely a joy to play.

The world is very gorgeous and mysterious. The gameplay is simple but provides some challenging moments and introduces new abilities at a good pace.

The game could use a little more polish. Sometimes if you move too far away from an NPC that is talking the voice will stop until you get close again. Also, sometimes the artifacts you knock off the golems can fall through the level and into areas you can't reach. But there are more than enough in the game to ensure you can complete the staircase with them even if you miss some.

I like how easy it is to replay the last bit and view each ending. I am looking forward to a sequel to explore the world and story more.
 
Kewl Munky

5.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 janvier 2018
While this game lacks in many ways, i still enjoyed it.
The story is... well, it exists, i guess.
You don't go fast all the time.
The combat feels awkward as you mainly fight golems. Those golems can only be beat once they did a certain move / amount of moves.
After defeating golems they drop artifacts, but sometimes they roll into the water or down into oblivion (doesn't matter if you only want to play through the story, which i recommend).
The slide seems to be useful a handful of times during the game. I used dash only to dodge.
There is not a lot of chaining moves together to fluently move through the level. Rather you do some jumping around, look around, collect stuff, fight stuff, jump around, rinse and repeat.

Still, i liked the aesthetics, atmosphere and the moveset. The game isn't too long (it took me 5 hours to beat it including some side-stuff. No Meditation or Challenges though) so it didn't overstay it's welcome.

9.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 février 2020
Pretty fun!
The story isn't so appealing, but the gameplay is where the game shines.
Open world parkour type platformer.
It reminded me a lot of a Prince of Persia type setting; even with some dagger of time powers... but with the free-running styles of Mirror's Edge.
Combat is about free-running around your opponents instead of turning it into an FPS, however.

The free-flow feeling of the free-running can be compared to A Story About My Uncle and the expansiveness of the world leaves you with many fun parkour paths to play around with. Lots of challenge stages to really test your skills as well.
 
A Lazy Monkey

Recommandé
7.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 février 2020
Playing on Linux Mint 19.3, game seems to run just fine on my rig at 30 FPS on high-max + vsync (i5 4570, GTX 1650). The game itself is a bit rough around the edges but still fun to play with really impressive visuals. I can get 60 FPS by dialing back the graphics but I don't really miss the framerate when I look at the scenery.

I guess my only complaint would be the sub-par voice acting. You can turn down the voice audio volume and read the subtitles, but then it gets tricky trying to figure out who's saying what.

I got it on sale, so I'd definitely recommend under those circumstances. Can't find too many good parkour games that run native on Linux if proton isn't your thing.

Évaluation publiée le 26 novembre 2017
I don't get this criticism. Game is fun and relaxing. Problem is not about game being "bad" (maybe voice acting). Problem is about players expecting it to be another game.

- Story was much better in "Story about my uncle", there is no "depth" nothing special
- Jumping around is more fun than in "SAMU", maybe because more open space and multi paths available from the beginning.
- If you want hard, fast, reflex needing parkour, go for Dead Core. This one is rather easy.
- This is NOT Mirrors Edge and I don't understand why people compare to it. There is a lot more parkour games better then white-red thing.
- Quite good graphics
- Fun with killing "things"

Non recommandé
0.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 décembre 2017
Produit remboursé

I want to like Downward, but Im not enjoying it. Its not that its a bad or poorly made game, it just isnt to my tastes, Ive got around 100 games in my "bought but havent played" list, and time is precious, so if it doesnt click with me, I need to move on.

Why am I bouncing off it?

The movement is a little stilted, its not "smooth" and "flowing" enough (eg mantling here, vs mantling in Doom2016 which feels good). The combat while novel is quite basic. The game seems to revolve around collecting little glowing blue things to power up, but I dont feel any particular motivation to do so outside of getting more abilities, getting them items themselves isnt enjoyable.

I cant find an in-game motivation to play this either: Im certain there is supposed to be a plot/storyline, but Im not following it, and the player character says insipid things with a dopey voice which, while it doesnt overly bother me, doesnt draw me in.

But nothing is critically bad or poorly made, so maybe *you* should give it a go, you might like it. I just dont.

PS - Im rating this "not recommended" due to my tastes - Downward is a nice example demonstrating the need for a middle category of "its fine, I neither recommend nor not recommend".
 
Benedict
1,515 produits enregistrés

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
11.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 mars 2019
Неплохой, но кривоватый платформер от первого лица в фентезийном сеттинге.

Ближайшие аналоги - Mirror's Edge и A Story About My Uncle.
На прохождение требуется 5-6 часов.

В целом всё более-менее сносно, но в игровой мир напихали кучу всего и кучу механик (при этом плохо их объяснив), и только к концу игры становится ясно, что всё оно по большому счёту и не нужно.
В итоге 80 % игры ты думаешь "Сколько вариантов... Куда идти и что вообще нужно делать ?", а оставшиеся 20 % "А зачем вообще всё ранее увиденное было добавлено в игру ?".
В общем, мир игры как-то неумело раздут и в нём явно много лишнего (как будто сначала задумывался с огромным размахом, а потом его знатно порезали, но осталось куча хвостов от первоначальной задумки).

Тем не менее, играть довольно интересно, даже если разобрался совсем чуть-чуть.
Дизайн очень неплох, техническая часть тоже вполне себе соответствует играм на UE4.

Для игры, сделанной командой из трёх человек - очень даже хорошо.
Для "отлично" нужно было либо делать масштабнее и полностью реализовать всё то, что выглядит сейчас "лишним", либо наоборот отрезать, чтобы игра выглядела продуманной, лаконичной и законченной.

Итого:
Хоть игра и с огрехами, но рекомендую.
 
himmler1

Évaluation publiée le 25 novembre 2017
My review of "Downward"
THE STORY - 6/10
Their isn't much of a story in this game as I expected. The game refers alot about "The Apocalypse" but we never get much detail about it.
THE GAMEPLAY - 9/10
The gameplay in this game is very well done. You have wall running, to little pods in the sky you can jump on, plus huge golems you have to fight in order to progress. This game definitly takes a slice in different.
LEVELING SYSTEM - 8/10
When launching this game up I just tought it was gonna be a normal boring parkour game... but it wasn't. This game has a pretty unique and interseting leveling system in where you collect sky shards to gain new abiltites like, more health.
OPEN WORLD - 9/10
This game has a vast open world experience. You can pretty much go anywhere on the map you want and not get a notfication saying "Your going the wrong way" or "This area is blocked off. Please finish the objective first."
TUTORIAL - 10/10
The tutorial for the begging of the game is easy to learn and great for begginers new to parkour games.
SCENERY - 10/10
The game does fantasic on showing you that what you are playing is just not a normal boring world... but a wonderful fantasty one.

Downward was a pretty fun game. The gameplay was the most enjoyable even with all the bugs like glitching through walls (a lot) or while using the pulley it sometimes shot me through the whole map. Friendly Neighbour Degenerate
278 produits enregistrés
0
7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
12.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 septembre 2017
A must have for every parcour fan in my opinion.
Bought the game on a whim when it first released and not once have I regretted it. For what the game has to offer the price is justified, especially taking into concideration it is still being worked on. Whicht was another big fear of mine when I bought it: Will the developers continue working on it?
Yes, yes they do. Frequent updates adding new content such as areas, storyline, skills, even entirely new gameplay mechanics while also fixing known bugs and slight improvements adding to the overall experience.
Talking of bugs:
Barely encountered any, to be precise I only ever had one.
Story
Admittedly not the games strongest point , interesting nonetheless while also explaining why the world looks like what it looks like. To be fair while I'm writing this the story is not yet finished, so it may get better as it goes (or worse, who knows). But I cannot really see the storyline ever being the main point why someone would love this game. As of right now not many NPCs as well and their stories are really lacking, no one could sugar coat that. What I like tho is that your player character is not mute and unquestioning of everything happening around him, a little plus there.
Graphics and performance
Here I have to admit that I am not the most demanding person in this aspect. Performance wise I used to have some minor lags throughout the entire game, but that seems to have been fixed somewhere along the way. Now the game plays very fluent for me on high settings even though my laptop already is a little bit outdated. Aesthetically I am just absolutely in love with this game . It looks unique and offers different designs throughout the areas with little repetitive elements while also managing to keep a certain style. At almost every point you can just stop and take in your surroundings for a view worthy of a screenshot gone wallpaper.
Mood
The game also doesn't fail to deliver feelings fitting for the areas. From the eerie feeling when first meeting the posessed skull in an almost completely dark underground passage to the warmth of the desert when climbing under the burning sun or the almost dream like feeling when you shift the planets to alter the world around you, mainly the lighting supported by sounds and music rarely fail to draw you into the mood they set. Rarely because, of course, no game is without flaw and I have one area (meeting the voice that guided you) where I am fairly disappointed because it feels like no mood is set at all, really unbefitting of the event occurring there.
Gameplay
Easy to pick up and learn controls. Gameplay mechanics are introduced to you through neat level design where you are, for example, confronted with a type of mechanism damaging your character in a secluded area first and you have to figure out how to stop it in order to proceed before it later becomes part of the normal areas. Not in a "let's take you aside to this tutorial area"-kinda way though, but more that it feels like part of the games flow. The parcour gets consistently more difficult preventing boredom and you can collect what serves as a kind of currency throughout the levels which can be used to level up and aquire skills that make the game easier. What's nice is that you can also make it through the game without leveling up at all, so no long drawn hunts for more points. You can also find another collectible scattered in every area and obtained from defeating enemys that form a staricase in your hub-area leading to something yet unknown because there are not yet enough of them in the world to complete the staricase. A secret to look foreward to in later updates. Enemys are found every now and then, not too scary encounters you get the hang of quickly but always able to kill you if you get too reckless. They also get more difficult as you go, mainly through increase in numbers tho where I would have wished for more diversity in design. Maybe thats still to come. In no way whatsoever are the encounters gruesome or brutal, you literally cannot even punch, so it's also suitable for the faint of heart. All areas of the game are also somewhat connected to each other, meaning you can access each one through climbing from where you started out at without porting or anything, which is important to me as it would take away from the games charme were you just being proted. For quicker acess in case you missed anything in an area portals are usable later on tho.

Summary:
The game feels good to play, looks gorgeous, has its hours of entertainment value and is actively being worked on by the devs. If you look for a parcour game that has its focus on exploring the world rather than action/ fight oriented (although found at times), this may be it. Despite the kinda weak story it is 100% worth its price.

Sorry for the long text, I got really lost in there :D
 
Sloraya
1

Évaluation publiée le 27 juin 2017
Avis donné pendant l'accès anticipé

Pssst, lis l'edit plus bas

Pendant les 5 premieres minutes tout se passe bien. Le jeu à l'air sympa et donne envie de continuer
Le probleme c'est que juste apres le 1er portail, je ramasse un item, je grimpe sur des trucs et au moment de me baisser pour passer dans le trou, mon jeu plante. Bon, je me dis que le jeu est en early acces, c'est normal qu'il soit imparfait. Aussitot je relance le jeu. Arrivé a l'endroit du precedant bug, mon jeu freeze a nouveau. Impossible donc d'aller plus loin
En faisant quelques recherches je vois que la solution proposée par les dev est de downgrade ma CG. Vous pensez vraiment que je vais installer une autre version de mon driver juste pour un petit jeu indé?
Au final j'y aurai joué 10min, dont 2 fois les 5min du debut.

EDIT :

Apres deux patchs de 1Go chacun, mon jeu fonctionne enfin. Il y a toujours des ralentissements, le framrate n'est clairmet pas stable sur mon pc mais bon, j'ai au moins pu passer le bug et continuer le jeu !

Évaluation publiée le 15 mai 2017
Avis donné pendant l'accès anticipé

Non recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 septembre 2020
This is very borderline between the yes and the no. I didn't hate my time with this game but I wasn't impressed either. It has cool maps with simple parkour mechanics but they quickly get repetitive since 90% of the paths are very straight forward. The anomalies help a little but since you can only use them where they are placed, they don't help to break the linearity at all. They're not fun new tools to use but barely keys to unlock new doors.

The optional areas and climbs are fine but all you get for it are a bunch of trinkets. The rewards quickly didn't mean much to me as they were only useless numbers going up in the corner of my screen. (After finishing the game, I still don't know if the one with a gear icon is useful for anything at all.)

The golem fights were straight up boring. Just dodge a little bit and wait for them to turn blue. The drones were fine as they were much quicker. The turrets were more fun because they could be integrated into a parkour area as a puzzle or an extra challenge.

The whole skills and upgrades system was, for them most part useless until the end boss. You have plenty of health and focus to go through the whole game.

Overall, a somewhat bland game but it definitely had a vision and some good ideas in there. I'm curious to see what else the devs will come up with. You could pick it up if you want a cheap parkour game but there are probably better choices out there.
 
Root
0

6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
23.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 juillet 2017
Avis donné pendant l'accès anticipé

With early access comes problems and this game has problems in spades, but I think if they can work out the kinks, they're gonna have a decent game. Expect the normal EA stuff (some wonky control mechanics, placeholder enemy models, Clipping through the environment, etc), but the worst for me is the broken "slingshot" mechanic. It's a core part of the game and required in order to complete certain parts, but every 5 or 6 times you use it, it launches you halfway across the map. I also had a helluva time trying to get this thing running at 60fps (GTX 1080, i5 6600k), but that may have been my own issue. Fore some reason, my monitor was registering at 30hz. Once I got that figured out, all was good... until the next time I loaded it up and started having issues again. Oh and when they say the game isn't finished, they don't just mean some tweaks and polish. The story just stops abruptly with a splash screen telling you they hope to complete the narrative.

All in all, it'll be worth a play for sure once it's complete. It's friggin' gorgeous to look at, at the very least.

Évaluation publiée le 29 mai 2017
Produit remboursé

Avis donné pendant l'accès anticipé

From the start I became really disinterested in this from the story aspect. To start with, absolutely hated the voice of your character.

I assumed that the tutorial was going to be something that was set aside from the actual game, but it seemingly acts as the actual start. Your character already has knowledge of whatever has happened to the world and acts in a "No way! This happened before so this cant be possible now!" kind of way. Im all for mystery and letting the player discover things by actually playing, but to immediately do something like that within seconds of starting the game while giving absolutely zero information is beyond annoying to me.

Movement system seemed clunky to me, though I could just be biased from Dishonored and Dying Light.

Thats about as far as I got. I was too alienated from the game right at the beginning with how they decided they were going to give the player information. Dunno if it changes later or not, but Im not willing to continue on to see. I was going to say no for recommending this, but now I see it actually has a demo to play. Have at it.

Buggy, clunky and an awful final boss fight.
The voice acting is cringy and the humor is meh.
Very bad work on lighting under high graphical settings, forcing me to hurt my config to have a decent sight on my path.
Boring plot, planet gameplay kinda dull.

Ziplines paths sometimes tossing you out of the path, making you lose progress without a say; had issues with world loading, making you sometimes fall through the map.

Lots of fixes and optimisation to do for an otherwise enjoyable dreamscape.
